THE WORLD BANK GROUP ARCHIVES
ORAL HISTORY PROGRAM
Transcript of interview with
W. DAVID HOPPER
April 2 and May 12, 2004 Washington, D.C.
Interview by: Kelly Feltault  1
Session 1 April 2, 2004 Washington, D.C.
[Begin Tape 1, Side A]
HOPPER: I'm David Hopper, or William David Hopper, to be entirely formal. I grew up in a family where you call everybody by their second name rather than the first name. Born on February 22 nd , 1927. Today is April the 2nd , 2004. I was born in Ottawa, Canada, and I'm still a Canadian.
FELTAULT: You never became a U.S. citizen?
HOPPER: No. I've been a long-term permanent resident of the United States. Someday I'll get around to citizenship, but ...
FELTAULT: Okay. It looks like we're registering just fine.
So today what I thought we'd do is start with some of the background information on you and move into your work in India in the '60s and the [Bernard R.] Bell Mission and then up through the '70s. Then I thought we'd possibly stop there, and then the second interview we would move into your work.
HOPPER: Do you want to shut that off just for a minute, and I'll introduce you, too?
FELTAULT: Sure. Okay.
[Interruption1
FELTAULT: So you said you were born in Ottawa.
HOPPER: Canada.
FELTAULT: Canada. And what were your parents' names and their occupations?
HOPPER: My father was Wilbert Clayton Hopper, called Bert. My mother was Eva Louella Hill, the maiden name. My father was an agriculturalist, first degree in agriculture, and then he moved to do his master's in agronomy and his Ph.D. at Cornell [University] in agricultural economics. I spent my first years of my life--they went down to Ithaca, New York, and Cornell when I was one and a half. He then joined the faculty at Cornell and started to work for USDA [U.S. Department of Agriculture], returned to Canada in 1938. My mother was a contralto soloist and then became very active in building houses and real estate. My father died in 1965. My mother died in 1986. My father had ALS, Lou Gehrig's disease, when he died. They're buried in a family burial plot up in Ottawa.
W. David Hopper April 2 and May 12, 2004 - Verbatim  2
My father, the last years in his life, was, worked in Australia and then was high commissioner-- which is the equivalent of ambassador in the British Commonwealth system--high commissioner to New Zealand and then came down here to Washington and spent the last ten years of his activity in Washington at the Canadian embassy.
FELTAULT: Okay. So that would have been '55 through '65?
HOPPER: This was--no. He retired in '59 from the Canadian foreign service.
FELTAUL T: Okay. Well, it's interesting: [know that you also went to Cornell and got your Ph.D. in agricultural economics.
HOPPER: And cultural anthropology.
FELTAULT: So was it a double?
HOPPER: It was a double major.
FELTAUL T: Double major. Let me ask you how much your father influenced you on going into that, that field.
HOPPER: A bit, but not--I grew up playing around with white rats, earning money producing white rats down in the basement, which was a very stinky business.
FEL TAULT: And what were the rats for?
HOPPER: I sold them to the National Research Council. They were genetically pure lines, and the National Research Council bought them at fifty cents a rat, which was a lot of money in those days, which I then invested in radios. I was a radio amateur. I never got on the air because the war broke out in 1939 in Canada, and 1 was banned. But I had a deep interest in radios and was determined to be a radio engineer. I spent some time at the edge of the Canadian artillery and so on.
But when the German--the Second World War kind of broke up, I found I was out of high school without really a proper high school diploma. I went to work in Toronto for a pollster outfit. I got interested in the fact that one of the polls I had to do was down in the wine growing area, the Niagara escarpment, which creates Niagara Falls. It's a big rock rise at the end of Lake Ontario, and I found myself involved in what they could do with the land, the farm areas, orchard areas, under the Niagara escarpment. Got interested in that, decided that the firm 1 was with was unlikely to survive (I was wrong), but I didn't--and pressure from family, you know: "Go get yourself a degree somewhere." And so 1 went to--tried Ontario Agricultural College, where my father graduated from back in 1920. And they were very kind, but I wasn't interested in the course work. I found ..
FEL TAULT: Why not?
W. David Hopper April 2 and May 12, 2004 - Verbatim  3
HOPPER: There wasn't enough science in it. It was--you moved in and you studied bee- keeping and you studied vegetable growing and you studied this and you studied that. But my radio things had put me--during my period in high school, for example, the physics teacher in high school refused to teach anything on electronics if I was sitting in the classroom. I taught it. This was part of it.
But I went to McGill University. I took a B.S.C. in agriculture. But the first two years in that is physics, mathematics, chemistry, and so on. I found this very, very suitable. And the last two years I studied economics and agricultural economics. Then I worked at Cornell one summer. I worked in Saskatchewan another summer. I went to different places. And I went back to Cornell to do a Ph.D.--well, to do my master's degree, actually.
FELTAULT: So you were only thinking master's at that time?
HOPPER: I was only thinking master's at that time. It was 1950. And I got assigned to milk marketing, and I worked in New York. I worked in New York one summer for milk marketing. Another summer I toured Europe on behalf ofthe--Iooking at the activities ofthe reconstruction of Europe. Was down in Italy, was impressed with the north Italians, had an Italian person who was working with me or traveling with me. The north was booming, Milan, et cetera, and as we moved south in Italy, it was, kept getting poorer and poorer. I had never seen such poverty as I saw in Naples and this kind of thing.
And we were sitting in a cafe in Palermo down in Sicily, and I said to Luigi, "I don't understand this. The north: booming economically. Down here: nothing. Same country, same language, same history. What's the problem?"
He said, "It's simple, it's simple. In the north you have to have money to get power. Down here you have to have power to get money." This was the home of the Mafia and so on. And that kind of stuck in my mind for some time.
I went to Cornell. This had occurred before I got to Cornell; it was in '49. I went to Cornell and got into milk marketing and decided that that isn't really what I wanted to do. And in the course of this, I worked with a man by the name of Forrest [Frosty] Hill, who was the head of ag economics at Cornell, one of my mentors, and he asked me what I thought was the most important thing in agriculture, global agriculture, over the course of the next twenty years. I said I didn't know. So he sent me offto read Frank Notestein, who was a demographer at Princeton [University] and so on. And it was quite clear that the demographers had taken a look at this. Notestein had, particularly, had taken a look at what occurred in our society, Western culture, as medicine improved and as our ability to handle things like smallpox and so on increased, and as incomes increased, that the numbers of children born into families was increasing and there was a population expansion, that birth issues before that, were pretty much forty per thousand for women/children and death rates were about forty per thousand, and we had a stability. Then suddenly death rates began to drop, but birth rates were culturally determined, and they stayed high, up at the forty per thousand, and you had a population expansion. And what was now clear was that the medical capabilities, our capabilities to handle death rates, was moving to the developing countries increasingly, and birth rates were culturally determined and remained high,
W. David Hopper April 2 and May 12, 2004 - Verbatim  4
and that you're going to have a major expansion and a demographic transition before the birth rates would begin to drop.
One of the places that had always interested me as a kid and so on, I used to read about India, British India. This seemed to apply to all of this, so I decided, in a discussion with Hill, to drop my milk marketing and pursue to a master's degree and to move over into taking a look at some other things. I went down and studied politics, political science, anthropology, did some work in law and slopped around the campus a bit.
FELTAULT: So it was very multi-disciplinary.
HOPPER: It was a multi-disciplinary search. And at the end of six months, I came and began to discuss all of this again with Hill. We decided that cultural anthropology and agricultural economics would mix. I did some work in soils, and I did some work in some other areas.
FELTAUL T: Now let me just interrupt you here for one second. It's interesting because economics and anthropology have not always been the best of friends as disciplines.
HOPPER: I'll tell you about that in a minute. All right?
FELTAULT: Okay. Good.
HOPPER: With anthropology, I went out and worked among the Navajo Indians and the Papago Indians out in the West and took a look at the work that Ruth Benedict and a series of others were doing in anthropology and found myself kind of deeply engrossed in anthropology. The decision was made that I should not do a master's degree but go directly for a Ph.D., and I got a Social Science Research Council grant to go live in India.
So I went and lived in a Village. There was a man from this village who was a student at Cornell, and it was his village I went to. The anthropology department of Cornell had a substantial grant from the Social Science Research Council and from other sources to do work in Peru and in . Thailand and in India. So I had those connections. And I went off and lived in this village in India, a remote part of India, not--it's an agricultural part. It's close to Benares. I was thirty miles from Benares and so on.
FEL TAUL T: Can you remember the name of it?
HOPPER: Oh, yeah, the village was called Senapur. It was in Kerakat tehsil and Jaunpur district. Jaunpur was an old Muslim area, but this was a Hindu village. And it was a very interesting thing. It was in the interior. It was four miles to the nearest road and six miles to the nearest market town. I lived there for two years. I was married and had my first wife. She was a nurse, so I was known as Dr. Sabb's [phonetic] husband because she kind of tended the people.
I struggled with what I was finding, trying to relate culture and agriculture. I did some farming, didn't know anything about rice but grew wheat. My first year growing wheat, I got it from the best farmer in the village, used his animals. I lived in a house, and there's a connection between
W. David Hopper April 2 and May 12,2004 - Verbatim  5
the workers and the landlords, the purjans and the jajmans. The purjans connected with my house did the work but [used] his animals, and I planted wheat. I had grown--my grandfather was a farmer and so on, so I had grown up partly on a farm. I knew what all this was about, and I did wheat. The understanding was that he was growing it in a field right beside mine, small plots, and if! got a good yield, then he would take my wheat, and that was that. If! didn't make at least what he got, then I'd pay him the difference. And the first year I paid him quite a bit. I discovered that you plant wheat when it's warm in India, and then you wait until the ground cools down enough. In Canada you plant wheat after the ground warms up enough. As my grandfather said, "You have to feel it through the soles of your feet," and I didn't feel it properly.
I then visited every research station across north India, all the agricultural research stations, and found that they were not getting nearly the yield my farmer was getting.
FELTAULT: Why was that?
HOPPER: Just the lack of-I mean, the research community was over here and they worked amongst themselves and so on. They didn't bother looking out what was going on among the agriculturalists. And I say the best farmer in the village. Look, there were farmers who were making a half, some of them less than a half, of the yields he was getting. He was just a very, very competent guy. The top twenty percent of the farmers were doing better than the agricultural research stations were. I wrote Hill about this, and we debated it back and forth. And I did some work otherwise.
My father, I told you, was in the foreign service. The High Commissioner to India, a man by the name of Escott Reid, was a good friend of my father's. He was a former professor at University of Toronto. During the Second World War, there was quite a number of these people from Toronto and many academic institutions who moved into Ottawa as part of the crew of building the Canadian participation in the Second World War or World War II.
Escott was there, and I visited Escott in Delhi, at both his request and per my father's suggestion: "You ought to go down and say hello to Escott." So I did. Escott--I went down dressed in basically Indian clothes, and Escott suggested that he'd like to give me a lunch for me, a whole lunch for me. I went to lunch, and Pandit [Jawahadal] Nehru was at the lunch and S. K. Dube, who was head of community development, was at the lunch, and a series of other people. Nehru suggested--he was prime minister--Nehru suggested that I go visit his daughter in Allahabad. I was seventy miles from Allahabad, and there's a big agricultural institute at Allahabad that was founded by the churches here, particularly the Methodist and Presbyterian here in the United States.
I went down to Allahabad. I bought a motor bike and kind of traveled around. I was only twenty miles from Sarnath, where Buddha preached his first sermon. I spent some time over there, beautiful old temples. It was the Ashokan capital back in 2000 BC or 250 BC. I spent time there. I spent a good deal of time in Benares. I went down every month and cashed some money and brought back medicine for my wife and other things and so on. Benares is a Hindu town, and I got to know Benares India University and so on.
W. David Hopper April 2 and May 12, 2004 - Verbatim  6
And I met Mrs. [Indira] Gandhi, before she was president of the Congress Party, at Nehru's suggestion, at her home in Allahabad. That was the family home, Nehru's home, her father's. I then--periodically I'd go.
Hill wrote me a letter to say that a man by the name of Art [Arthur T.] Mosher was coming, former director at Allahabad, a [University of] Chicago graduate in agricultural economics but before that an agriculturalist from University of Illinois. But he had been director of the Allahabad Agricultural Institute for many years. So I biked down to Allahabad to see Mosher. Mosher and I found that we were great, great--I mean, I'd been six months in the village and I hadn't sorted anything out. It was just culture and so on. Mosher had also done a Ph.D. at Chicago, focused on this issue of the villages in India and agriculture and so on, not from the demographic point of view, which was my main concern, but as how do you feed the people.
Mosher and I took a trip and sat in the back of a truck while they drove up to Lucknow, which is the capital of Uttar Pradesh. And we sat back there and talked all the way up to Lucknow, which is about a five-hour drive. They did what they had to do, and then we drove back--or were driven back by the others from the Institute but sat in the back of the truck and talked for another five hours. Mosher just really was the light in sorting out the difference between economics and anthropology.
Now, this comes back to the story, because when I gave my Ph.D. thesis, the anthropologists at the table were concerned that I was talking about economic man too much in this.
FELTAULT: In the sense of Adam Smith's ...
HOPPER: In the sense of Adam Smith's and in the sense of [David] Ricardo and so on and so forth and the others, that there is an economic response that's here. And the anthropologists were concerned that there wasn't enough culture, that I really didn't spend the time on the culture. I did. I did both in the thesis, but there was an economic trend running through it as well as a cultural trend.
Example: storage of grain. They had primitive storage. This was a mud village. It was basically mud houses. There were a few--a couple, three, four, five, six brick houses, but this was because they had income from outside. People wanted our glass bottles that we finished. They would break them and they would put the glass into the mud that was around the grain storages, so that if the rats came at it, they would get their paws to bleed and so on and they would no longer try to--they would drill holes in this thing that held the grain. You had grain storages. They were primitive, yes. Why did you have grain storage? I mean, why not sell it? Well, number one, you had drought potential, so you had to carry it through. Number two, if you had a marriage, you wanted to serve the baraal, the male, the groups that came along with the groom to be married to the local woman--you wanted to feed them last year's grain because you wanted to make it quite clear that you were sufficiently affluent to be able to provide your daughter and receive him as a son-in-law by serving last year's grain because you had enough grain to do this. So all of this was part of the cultural element of it.
W. David Hopper April 2 and May 12,2004 - Verbatim  7
There was a guy digging a well. I wanted him to go down the--India was advertising. I had a radio, all-India radio, a radio that was fixed-tuned to the local radio stations. I had a guy from the local town come in and ask me if I could keep my canned goods for him because we did use some cans, and he heard that we had, we used a toilet. Now, the toilet's another story, but the--it was in this house, and I said yes. Well, he said, the toilet paper comes wrapped in a cardboard roll. I said yes. He'd like me to save those for him because he was wrapping--he was in the market town six miles away--he was wrapping these and creating what is known in the radio trade as a tank circuit. Well, I knew immediately what it was. This is a variable condenser and a coil, and you loop it through and you get different frequencies than you have, and this is how you adjust the frequency on a radio. And what he wanted to do was to go around to the villages where you had this all-India radio battery-driven machine, which got only one station, namely, India station, but he wanted to convert it so that they could listen to a short-wave station that came in from Ceylon, Radio Ceylon, which all India listened to because it's sort of movie music and so on. But on the India radio station, what you got were deadly, deadly speeches and discussions of ...
FELTAUL T: Government type.
HOPPER: That's right, of how to do this and how to do that. But one of the things they wanted to do was, when you dug a well, make sure that you put a cement wall around the well down through the first aquifer that came in because everybody used the fields. I was unique in that the villagers built a little septic tank and a toilet for me, and you flushed it with a bucket, because they didn't want my wife exposed to--we were the pink race, and sitting out in the fields doing your morning duties and so on was not what they felt that she ought to have. So we flushed it with a bucket and out it went. But the upper aquifer had a lot of human waste on it, particularly on the fields around the village, because that was a good manure and this is what you did.
But I said to this guy that, you know, I was digging a well, and I said, "Let's put the wall around it like the government radio was saying you ought to do, a cement wall so that you got it from the second aquifer." In other words, the water had been filtered a little more and so on so some of this stuff came into it.
Now, the Indian at that time really didn't believe-I mean, diseases (malaria, et cetera) were caused by bhoots. These were old crone women who paddled the fields at night. They walked in translucent garments, and their feet were pointed backwards. And if you saw one on the path, you better get off fast because she'd latch onto you and then you'd bring her home, latched onto you. Then she'd sit at the head of the bed--not so that you could see her--but she just sat at the head of the bed, and you had malaria. You got your illnesses. And so this was the belief.
I said to him, "You've got to build your cement wall."
He said, "Why?"
And I told him about the germs in the aquifers and so on.
W. David Hopper April 2 and May 12,2004 - Verbatim  8
He looked at me, and he said finally, "Hopper, you believe in the germ theory of disease?" in effect. I mean, it was in Bhojpuri, which is the local dialect.
And I said, "Yes, I do."
He said, "Have you ever seen a germ?"
Now, there's no point in getting into microscopes and so on and so forth and wee beasties and the rest of it. I said, "Well, no."
He said, "Aha!" He said, "I've seen a bhoot." But he did put in a cement wall. [Laughter]
Another farmer, who in discussing this I was saying about using some fertilizer, and he said, "Well, is it the right thing to do?"
I said, "What do you mean by the right thing to do?"
He said, "You know, is this what God would have told"--not God but one of the incarnations of God, Lord Krishna--"told to the charioteer," in a very, very long Hindu poem, several thousand verses. And the charioteer--the Hindus at that time believed that you started battle at sunrise and stopped at sunset. You cleared the battlefield and so on and so forth, and the next day it was the other man's turn to be the attacker and you would be the defender, and the lord was out there ready to move his troops, and he just didn't do it and he didn't do it, and the charioteer turned to him and said, "Why are you not moving?" He said, "Well, because is this really worth it, all the blood and the death and so on and so forth?" The charioteer more or less said--and the charioteer was an impersonation of Lord Krishna--the charioteer said, "That's my problem. I'm God. You just do it. And the right thing to do is to bring those troops together." And that's what was done.
So the old farmer tells me, "Is using fertilizer the right thing to do?"
1 discussed it with him and so on and so forth. 1 said I really didn't know in Lord Krishna's terms whether it was the right thing to do.
He said, "Well, I'd have to sort that out."
I said, "Well, you know, it will make a big difference in terms of your yield."
We talked about that, and he finally looked at me and said, "You know, I'm an imperfect man. I'm an imperfect man." He said, "I really want to do the right things, but then you come along and tell me this might be a way to increase yield. 1 don't know whether that's the right thing to do or not." He said, "It sounds like a good idea." [Laughter]
So it was this kind of balance between culture and economic man.
FEL TAULT: Economic man is also, you know, feeding a few more people.
W. David Hopper April 2 and May 12, 2004 - Verbatim  9
HOPPER: Feeding a few more people and so on and so forth.
This came up at my Ph.D. thesis. Mosher was on my committee now. He was on the faculty at Cornell. And the anthropologists had some questions as to whether that I really hadn't done the proper thing on the culture side. And the economists at my table--because it was agricultural economics as my mother major and economics as my minor--the economists at the table were saying, well, I found too much culture. [Laughter] And Mosher kind of got into it and said, "Well, Dave, what you're really saying is that there's a balance between culture."
I said, "Yes."
And the anthropologists said, "But that's not adequate. I mean, it's got to be culturally focused."
Mosher took on my side with this balance. The economists kind of lined up because they were unhappy with the culture components in it. Mosher kind of took them on, and it was an hour debate, which I was out of. The decision was finally made, "Well, okay. All right, we'll give him the degree. " [Laughter] So there you are.
It's that balance that was there, and that balance I brought pretty much to what I do. I take a look--you go down through the Bell Mission report, and you'll find I wrote several of the papers in it. [Sir John] Crawford--I wrote with Crawford. Crawford did the main draft for the agricultural section. It has been a balance that I've sought between the culture element, the way this is evolving, and the economic element.
You'll find that I had problems with the Swadeshi movement in India, which is "let's build everything at home and not rely on the outside" and so on, and "if we didn't invent it ourselves or patent it ourselves, then we don't want it," et cetera, that kind of dominates a good deal of even Hinduism today, the VHP [Vishwa Hindu Parishad] and the shrine of Babri Masjid and BJP [Bharatiya Janata Party] government in India. It's a very difficult thing that India had to struggle with, and at the Bank and in Delhi when I was a vidyarti or a student in this thing, I was struggling with just that, that set of issues. It was Mosher who kind of defended me, but it was Mosher who clarified it.
FELTAULT: Let me back up and ask you just some clarifying questions. Okay, so who at Cornell was in the anthropology department at that time?
HOPPER: Ah. A man by the name of Morris Opler was the--Opler, O-P-L-E-R. He was the anthropologist who was most deeply involved in India. Opler and I battled whenever he came out to India because I was not doing what he wanted to do. I wasn't chasing the Brahmins around trying to find out what they were doing and, well, renting and so on and so forth. I was out in the field looking at soil types. I analyzed the whole ofthe soils in the village and got maps made and so on and so forth of the village plots and what the [inaudible] were looking after. He just was not--he didn't feel I was being an anthropologist.
When I returned to Cornell after I left the village--I was in the village about two years. I got there in September of 1953, and I left when it began to get hot in July of '55. I spent the better
W. David Hopper April 2 and May 12, 2004 - Verbatim  10
part of a month over at the Maharaja of Benares, at his place doing some work that he wanted done but really organizing my notes and getting ready to go home. It took about eleven trunks to come back with the paper that I had because I did huge amounts of questionnaire work in the village: economics, what were they doing, what were their labor relations, and so on. I wrote several articles while I was there on this.
The return back, and went back to Cornell, and Opler and I met, and he told me that he found my work interesting but not--it wasn't anthropology.
I went to the head of the anthropology department and said, "Look, I've put a fair amount of money into this or a fair amount of work into this."
He said he understood Opler's problems. He said, "We'll change you." So he changed me over to a man who was working at that time in Peru and who had been an anthropologist in Brazil when he was young, did his Ph.D. on a tribal group in Brazil that had never really been studied and so on. He was quite an amazing guy. But they needed somebody who had expertise on India, and Mosher was fortunately on the faculty then. So I got Art Mosher to come in on my committee. And that was the mixture. Qpler opposed it all the way through.
FELTAULT: He remained on the committee then?
HOPPER: No, no. He did not. He was dropped. But the other guy was very, very understanding and so on. That was how the anthropologist played out.
FELTAULT: Was he expecting you to do obviously some structuralist ...
HOPPER: No. What he was interested in was, quote, "the disappearing values in the society." There was changes occurring. They had built a school back in 1865. After the mutiny, there'd been a meeting ofthe--in 1857-there'd been a--British troops had come in and had disrupted a wedding party that was out on the road four miles away from this village. The village is Senapur, which means "the Place of the Army." And it was settled back in the 17th century, mid- I i h century, by a family, a large family group, that came in, and that was their thing, because the Dacoits or the tribals, et cetera, were all outsiders. This was where they did, and they built a community that moved around and so on. But that's where the main group were. This village was, had that main group in it, six Bhatis [phonetic] or six tribal families, if you want--related but nevertheless independent. So the village was important.
The British came back after this battle of the troops. These were sepoys, primarily, Indian troops that were working for the East India Company before Britain came in as an official thing. They came back into the village and they hung, or hanged, fourteen people in that village for what they had done to the troops. And that garden where this hanging took place is still there. It's a very important point in the village. But the village decided, the villagers decided, the landlords in this village and the aristocracy group, the Kshatriyas or Rajput, decided that they would--their young people had to get income, and the British are now going to tum against them, so we better get them educated.
W. David Hopper April 2 and May 12,2004 - Verbatim  11
So they built a school in 1865. It was only Rajputs who went to that school. That's all, their sons, only Rajput males. They had a school. This is the young man that I met at Cornell who was also studying for a Ph.D. He was older than I was. He had finished up at [Balwant] Rajput College in India in Agra. They had a group that came from either that village or the surrounding villages. The head of the Indian civil service was one of these. The dean of the Lucknow law school was another one, et cetera. It was quite an educated group.
When I went to the villagers, the school was still there. It was still active. But this is part of where the change was, and it was moving. And Opler was unhappy that we weren't getting what was it. What was the culture? Yeah, now we're modernizing, but really what was this cultural base? And what I was interested in was the modernizations and how did I get them to, instead of producing, in the case of my best farmer, two tons per hectare of wheat and two and a half tons of rice per hectare, how did I get them producing four tons of wheat per hectare which, you know, nobody in India was producing, but that's a reasonable yield where I came from. So Opler and I just disagreed. I was looking to the future and he was looking to the past. And that's where it was.
One of the things I did when I got to the village, I met with the elders and said, "Okay, one of the things you're going to have to confront is the fact that I'm going to be here. I'm going to be here . for a couple of years, and I'm going to be asking a lot of damn fool questions to people. These are going to be randomly selected households." It wasn't quite random because I had to put the important ones in but, basically, and randomly selected households.
